awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Task-Cognizant Sparse Sensing for Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
As big data applications continue to grow in size and number, it is of crucial importance to deal only with measurements that are informative for a specific inference task in order to limit the required sensing cost, as well as the related costs of storing or communicating the data. To this end, this project develops a new paradigm of compressive sensing for random processes, where the signal compression and reconstruction strategies are designed to be task-cognizant, hinging on useful signal statistics rather than the original random signals. This research leads to major sensing energy savings, and can benefit a plethora of energy-efficient sensing applications such as location-aware services, weather monitoring, spectrum monitoring, and radio astronomy.

The main goal of this project is to significantly reduce the cost of sensing as well as the related storage and communication requirements by offering innovative sensing approaches tailored to the inference task of interest. Different from existing compressive sampling, the proposed research leverages the inherent structures of signal statistical information in order to enable reliable inference from sparsely sampled data, rather than solely relying on signal sparsity to enable compression. As such, a new approach to sparse sensing is introduced for random processes, which reveals the fundamental limits of compression in relation to the degrees of freedom inherent to the underlying statistical structure, even in the absence of signal sparsity. Efficient inference techniques and deterministic compressive sampler designs are put forth to affect major savings in the sensing costs while achieving the desired inference quality. These basic results open up opportunities for efficient handling of data-intensive sensing applications in which inference from random processes is of foremost importance.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops low-cost sparse sensing mechanisms that are cognizant of the inference task of interest, in order to significantly reduce the cost of sensing as well as the related storage and communication requirements. Different from existing compressive sampling for signal reconstruction, this research focuses on efficient reconstruction of various useful signal statistics from compressive measurements. The developed compressive statistical sensing framework leverages the inherent structures of signal statistical information to enable reliable inference from sparsely sampled data, rather than solely relying on signal sparsity to enable compression. A new approach to sparse sensing for random processes is introduced, which reveals the fundamental limits of compression in relation to the degrees of freedom inherent to the underlying statistical structure, even in the absence of signal sparsity.

 

Intellectual Merit

The project outcomes include a set of theory, algorithms, and sparse sampler design for the compression of random processes and reconstruction of useful statistics for the inference task at hand, bypassing the unnecessary step of recovering the original random signals. The developed theory and algorithms are demonstrated on well-appreciated signal processing applications, including massive MIMO systems for wireless communications and radar.

 

In terms of theory, a major outcome is the development of a theory for compression of random processes and reconstruction of useful statistics for the inference task at hand, bypassing the unnecessary step of recovering the original random signals. A new framework of Compressive Statistical Sensing is developed, which reveals the fundamental limits in compression for non-sparse signals, formulate a transformed measurement system to offer closed-form solutions to statistics estimation from compressive data, and provide a deterministic design approach for the compressive samplers with guaranteed reconstruction of useful statistics. Such a framework is studied in depth for covariance and spectra as second-order statistics, as well as for third-order cumulants as higher-order statistics. For each of these cases, our results illustrate the unique structural information in the statistic of interest, and reveal the corresponding sufficient conditions for sampling and the strongest allowable compression ratio in the absence of any signal sparsity. When the sufficient sample conditions are satisfied, the developed reconstruction algorithm reduces to a simple least-squares method with closed-form solutions, which is not only computationally efficient, but also amenable to rigorous performance analysis. Compressive sampler design that meets such sufficient conditions at the lowest sampling rate is also provided.

 

Another major outcome is the design of sparse sensing mechanisms to effect major energy savings while guarantee a prescribed sensing quality. The developed compressive samplers represent well-structured deterministic sensing functions that are applied to the data for the specific sensing task at hand, as opposed to random projections used in conventional random samplers. Such deterministic and sparse sampling mechanisms are amenable to low-cost hardware implementation with respect to random ones. Number theory on various types of minimum sparse rulers is investigated for such sparse sampler design for various tasks involving second-order and third-order statistics.

 

The third major outcome is a variety of efficient algorithms developed for solving structured low-rank matrix minimization problems, along with their adaptive and distributed implementations for network sensing problems. The project results in closed-form solutions to reconstruction of the statistics of interest from compressive samples. These formulations may involve one-dimensional or high-dimensional atomic norm minimization (ANM) for single or multiple measurement vectors, which incurs huge computational cost and may become too costly for practical applications. To tackle the computational complexity issue, an efficient optimization technique for gridless two-dimensional line spectrum estimation is developed, named decoupled atomic norm minimization (D-ANM). The developed D-ANM technique reduces the computational complexity by several orders of magnitude with respect to the problem size. It also retains the benefits of ANM in terms of precise signal recovery, small number of required measurements, and robustness to source correlation.

 

The fourth major outcome is the demonstration of the developed theory and algorithms on well-appreciated signal processing applications, including massive MIMO systems for wireless communications and radar. For instance, the compressive statistical sensing framework is applied to millimeter-wave massive MIMO systems to accurately estimate the desired channel information, such as path angular directions, channel state information or channel covariance. Owing to the sample efficiency and computational efficiency of this framework, the channel sensing problem can be solved within a very short sensing time at affordable computational costs, even for large-size, high-dimensional massive MIMO channels.

 

Broader Impacts

The outcomes of this project broadly impact the design of energy-efficient sensing applications, such as next-generation wireless communication systems with massive MIMO, spectrum monitoring, radio astronomy, etc. The knowledge gained in this project has been used by the PI to develop new teaching materials and enhance curriculum in signal processing, for both undergraduate and graduate education. This project provides direct training opportunities for PhD students and postdoctoral researchers, who will enter the workforce with well-developed skills in STEM.
